snippet: A case dealing with federal benefits for gay couples — not with the legality of their marriages — could be the first involving same-sex marriage to reach the Supreme Court.
abstract: Federal appeals court rules unanimously that the law declaring marriage to be a union between a man and a woman discriminates against married same-sex couples by denying them the same benefits afforded to heterosexual couples; decision will have no immediate effect because the court stays its ruling in anticipation of an appeal to the Supreme Court.

byline.original: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE and ETHAN BRONNER

lead_paragraph: A case dealing with federal benefits for gay couples — not with the legality of their marriages — could be the first involving same-sex marriage to reach the Supreme Court.

headline.main: Appeals Court Turns Back Marriage Act as Unfair to Gays
headline.print_headline: U.S. Appeals Court Turns Back Marriage Act as Unfair to Gays

keywords.value: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
keywords.name: subject
